etymologies: late 19th century: from extra-‘outside’ + a shortened form of interpolate

definitions: extend the application of (a method or conclusion) to an unknown situation by assuming that existing trends will continue or similar methods will be applicable

examples.text: the results cannot be extrapolated to other patient groups
it is always dangerous to extrapolate from a sample

shortDefinitions: extend application of method or conclusion to unknown situation by assuming that existing trends will continue or similar methods will be applicable

examples.text: the figures were extrapolated from past trends

shortDefinitions: estimate or conclude something in this way

definitions: extend (a graph, curve, or range of values) by inferring unknown values from trends in the known data

examples.text: the low-temperature results can be extrapolated to room temperature

shortDefinitions: extend by inferring unknown values from trends in known data
